summary:
Natallia E. Uzunbajakava holds a Ph.D. in physics and an engineering degree (the University of Twente) and certification in Strategic Management & Innovation (CBS). 
She demonstrated impact by delivering costs savings, new product propositions, support of product launches, claim substantiations, regulatory clearance and new scientific discoveries.
She pioneered Raman Spectroscopy for imaging of single human cells (two awards at ‘Focus on Microscopy’). Her joined investigations with Dr. Botchkareva and Dr Westgate explained mode of action of low fluence light pulses resulting in long-term hair reduction in photoepilation. Collaboration with prof. van de Kerkhof deepened understanding of Sensitive Skin (‘Sensitive Skin Syndrome’ Eds. Honari, Andersen, Maibach 2017). Research within European project CLASSIC (ID 607886) culminated in a discovery photoreceptors in the skin and hair follicle cells as new molecular targets for light therapies (Keith Foundation Best of Photobiomodulation Session, ASLMS 2017; Molecular Dermatology, Eds. Botchkareva, Westgate, 2020). 
Dr. Uzunbajakava has 43 publications, incl. 3 Book Chapters, 22 Technical Notes at PHILIPS. She holds 27 US granted patents and applications, lectures nationally and internationally at an intersection of biophotonics and skin biology. Her H-Index is 18 (Scopus @September 2023). 

EXPERTISE: 
APPLIED PHYSICS, Biophysics, LIGHT-TISSUE INTERACTION, SPECTROSCOPY, MICROSCOPY, PHOTOBIOLOGY, Skin & Hair Physiology, in vitro & ex vivo Skin Models, Clinical Studies, LEAN, DfSS.

IMCAS Academy member, peer REVIEWER of BIOMEDICAL Optics Express, Experimental DERMATOLOGY, Archives of Dermatological Research, OPTICS Express, Lasers in Surgery & Medicine, Journal of Photochemistry & PHOTOBIOLOGY.

treasury_media.title: Beauty door de jaren heen - Philips
treasury_media.description:
A joined project with the Dutch National Rijksmuseum, where Bianca M. du Mortier, curator of the museum, tells about Beauty Rituals.
Beauty Rituals of the Middle Ages, as we see them reflected by masterpieces disposed in the museum.
And Beauty Rituals of Today and Tomorrow, enabled by Science and Innovation.

treasury_media.title: Towards differential Light-Based Therapy for cutaneous conditions. ESDR 2017.
treasury_media.description:
This study evaluated the dose-response of primary human papillary and reticular DF to visible light. 
Differential impact of light on dermal fibroblast subpopulations may open new avenues for developing therapies for various cutaneous conditions, e.g. treatment of keloids, fibrosis, alopecia or differential therapy under distinct stages of wound healing.
The 47th Annual ESDR meeting, Salzburg. 27-30 September 2017.

treasury_media.title: Unraveling insights on the molecular, cellular, and biophysical impact of light on skin stem cells towards regenerative therapy.
treasury_media.description: CLaSSiC was an interdisciplinary EU FP7 Marie Curie funded project and a collaborative network between the Centre for Skin Sciences, the University of Bradford and Philips under the European Industrial Doctoral training scheme.

projects.title: CLaSSiC - Light Impact on Skin Stem Cells
projects.description:
http://www.skinlight-classic.eu

The project CLaSSiC is dedicated to unraveling mechanisms of light interaction with skin & hair stem cells, paving a path towards regenerative therapy for skin and hair disorders. Research activities cover fundamental understanding of skin stem cell interaction with light at a molecular level; development of tissue models in which to explore functional biophysics; optical modelling; experimental biomedical optics; all culminating in a product design. 
A team of three Early Stage Researchers will work on the project at the Center for Skin Sciences, University of Bradford and Philips Research Eindhoven, guided by scientists with experience in both academic and industrial environment.

projects.title: SENSuaL: A physico-biological model of skin irritation following mechanical and light-based challenges
projects.description:
Acute and chronic traum-iterative challenges of the skin are the reality of life. The skin has developed during evolution as the organ to adapt to these challenges and by doing so to protect the ‘milieu interieur’.
Physical challenges can be: (i) acute mechanical challenge (wounding) or chronic mechanical challenges (rubbing, friction, and shaving) and (ii) photo damage, again as an acute or as a chronic form. 
The response pattern of the skin is intended to recover the integrity of the skin and to protect against microbial and chemical damage. The initial part of the response is an inflammatory response to eliminate body-foreign elements or altered self (damaged cells) and the secondary response is regeneration of the skin. 
The response pattern may follow a normal dynamics with the usual subjective sensations of the skin (a certain degree of pain or itch), with some degree of inflammation (erythema, induration). Some subjects may have aberrant responses with feeling of excessive irritation or signs of irritation (Koebner phenomenon in psoriasis).
Some challenges have become part of our way of living: shaving or laser treatment in skin care procedures (e.h., hair removal using photo-epilation and skin rejuvenation using fractional photo-thermolysis). However, irritation of the skin and the feeling of burning skin remain to be a serious limitation for these common procedures. The latter one imposes restrictions on the efficacy of skin care procedures and on the applicability for all ethnic groups and in particular for subjects with the so-called “sensitive skin” .
This proposal aims to find out the biological reality of  “ sensitive skin “ and irritation originating due to the following procedures:
I.	mechanical shaving, incl. dry and wet shaving 
II.	light-based skin treatment, such as:
a.	fractional photothermolysis 
b.	light-based hair removal using IPL or a laser source.
